As the first or corresponding author (including co-authors), he has published more than 110 papers in leading international journals such as Physical Review Letters, National Science Review, Science Advances, Nature Communications, Nature Reviews Materials, Nature Reviews Physics, Reports on Progress in Physics, and Science Bulletin, among which 14 are ESI highly cited papers. His research results have been selected multiple times as Editorsâ€™ Suggestions and have been featured by media outlets such as APS, AIP, Phys.org, Physics Buzz, and Science Daily. His publications have accumulated over 13,200 citations with an H-index of 52. He has been listed several times among the Highly Cited Researchers and the worldâ€™s top 2% scientists (career-long impact). He received the First Prize of the Ministry of Education Natural Science Award and the â€œWei Moâ€™an Acoustics Awardâ€ from the Shanghai Acoustical Society, and his students won the National Gold Medal of the China International College Students Innovation Competition. Patents related to acoustic metamaterial absorbers have been successfully transferred and applied to large-scale wind-tunnel compressor noise-reduction systems, achieving low-noise operation of major equipment. We are always seeking outstanding postdoctoral researchers and highly motivated Ph.D. and M.S. students to join our group. Prospective candidates are encouraged to contact Prof. Yong Li (yongli@tongji.edu.cn) for further information. ğŸ§  Research Interests1. Manipulation of Exotic Fields with Acoustic Functional Materials This direction focuses on the fundamental mechanisms of acoustic field manipulation in artificial structures and functional materials, exploring wave propagation, interference, and localization in complex media. The research emphasizes resonant coupling, wavefront shaping, and nonreciprocal sound transmission to elucidate the physical nature of soundâ€“matter interactions, providing theoretical foundations and design principles for precise acoustic energy control and advanced acoustic devices. 2. Application Explorations of Acoustic Functional Materials Aimed at the noise control and acoustic optimization needs of major equipment, this research advances the applied fundamentals of acoustic functional materials. It develops high-performance sound-absorbing metamaterials and multifunctional composites based on deep-subwavelength structural design, and systematically investigates energy management mechanisms involving resonance, coupling, interference, and dissipation. The goal is to realize broadband, efficient, lightweight, and programmable sound absorption and insulation schemes that support innovation in transportation, aerospace, and precision acoustic engineering. 3. Non-Hermitian and Topological Acoustics This research area explores the emerging intersection of non-Hermitian physics and topological acoustics, focusing on the acoustic realization and dynamics of gain/loss modulation, exceptional points (EPs), and topological edge states. It uncovers new physical phenomena such as nonreciprocal sound propagation, asymmetric mode coupling, and robust energy transport. By constructing non-Hermitian topological structures and nonreciprocal acoustic channels, the work advances robust acoustic communication, reconfigurable wave control, and intelligent acoustic
